docs.lead_paragraph: The number of babies born on the way to the hospital in Los Angeles County is rising, and some health care professionals are blaming traffic congestion. The number of children born en route to a hospital increased to 204 in 2000 from 175 in 1997 in the county, where the average freeway speed has dropped to 37 miles an hour. The trip to the delivery room is also getting longer because of hospital and clinic closures in recent years.

headline.main: National Briefing | West: California: It's A Freeway And A Delivery Room

docs.lead_paragraph: A YEAR ago, a 19-year-old named Mishgan was confined to this village 37 miles south of Kabul, unschooled and without hope that the future held anything but the prospect of more children being pulled from her slight frame. Then came Sept. 11, the American bombardment of Afghanistan, the Taliban's flight and the installation of the interim Afghan government. The events reverberated around the globe, but registered as barely a tremor in her life. ''There are the same difficulties, with or without the Taliban,'' said Mishgan, who, like many Afghan women, uses only one name.

headline.main: The Burkas Come Off, But Equality Falters At the Edge of Kabul

docs.abstract: Urban women of Afghanistan are tasting freedom with departure of Taliban rule, but in villages, where 80 percent of country's women live, things are as they were; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: I thank Rebecca Johnson for her courage in sharing her story (Aug. 25). She not only opens her heart to us and honors Luke's struggle for life but also responsibly provides what will undoubtedly prove life-altering infor-mation for many readers and their babies. Alison Weiss New York

docs.lead_paragraph: In 1935, my mother had pre-eclampsia; my sister lived. In 1955, I had pre-eclampsia; my daughter is alive. But knowledge is about as limited today as it was then. Treatment, then and now, includes bed rest, restricted diet and Epsom salts or diuretics. Not much progress has been made in the past 67 years. We still do not know what causes pre-eclampsia and have no new methods of treatment. Why? Mary Fogarty South Weymouth, Mass.
docs.abstract: Mary Fogarty letter on Rebecca Johnson's experience with pre-eclampsia, and how little is known about pregnancy condition

docs.lead_paragraph: Rebecca Johnson's account of her traumatic pregnancy -- and of her son's losing fight for life -- prompted an overwhelming response. Readers said it held them riveted even as it moved them to tears. Our report on walrus shoots, on the other hand, prompted many to declare open season on the big-game hunter featured.

docs.lead_paragraph: I too had early onset, fulminant pre-eclampsia and none of the risk factors associated with this disease. But I was extraordinarily lucky in that my baby, with a few more weeks under her belt than Luke, survived and has no complications from her prematurity. I wish Rebecca the best of luck with a second pregnancy and applaud her bravery. I am also grateful to her for the most intelligent summary of the scientific literature on the disease that I have seen. With so many unknowns and so much at risk, informing ourselves is all we can do. Sarah Krakoff Boulder, Colo.
docs.abstract: Sarah Krakoff letter on Rebecca Johnson's account of traumatic pregnancy recalls own experience (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Having read your article, I now understand why obstetricians are fleeing the specialty in such numbers. After her son died, Rebecca Johnson tells us she consulted a number of doctors. One physician, she writes, ''wouldn't even let'' her tape their conversation. But surely she must know that for a doctor who was not on the scene to second-guess the decisions of those who were is highly unethical. She goes on to note that the ''fear of litigation'' was ''palpable'' in her own doctor's written account of her treatment and that ''all doctors are defensive about malpractice and none more so than obstetricians.'' It is little wonder. And if I were an obstetrician, I would be heading for the nearest exit, too. Elaine M. Stainton Brooklyn
docs.abstract: Elaine M Stainton letter on Rebecca Johnson's account of fateful pregnancy; sympathizes with physicians' fears of lawsuits (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: I found myself rooting for this child, even as your writer so poignantly described each hurdle, and I was certain he would pull through. So I was stunned as I read on and realized that Luke would indeed not be able to win this fight. Those paragraphs describing his final moments came so fast they caught me off guard, and I found myself fighting back tears. Luke's story was filled with almost nothing but sadness, but I am grateful that Rebecca shared it. In the end, she says she ''didn't know Luke,'' but I have to disagree. She describes him in a way only a mother can describe her own child, with perceptiveness and great sensitivity. Jean Sommer St. Louis
docs.abstract: Jean Sommer letter sympathizes with Rebecca Johnson's August 25 story of her traumatic pregnancy

docs.lead_paragraph: When Rebecca Johnson said that pre-eclampsia was formerly called toxemia, I was stunned. My mother-in-law said that she had toxemia when she was pregnant with my husband, but I never before understood what it meant to have that condition. He was born a month premature at less than four pounds. It took a lot of improvising in 1930 to keep such a small baby alive: she pumped her breast milk because he was too weak to nurse; she heated bricks to put under the crib to keep him warm. Today he's still in excellent health at age 71. I'm glad Rebecca is willing to have another child. My mother-in-law had an uneventful pregnancy and a full-term baby a few years later. Joan Bjorklund Chicago
docs.abstract: Joan Bjorklund letter on her mother-in-law's experience with baby born prematurely in 1930 because of pre-eclampsia or toxemia; comments on Rebecca Johnson's August 25 article (S)
